**Orcrist** is an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic"), and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is an [elven broadsword](/wiki/Elven_broadsword "Elven broadsword").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [6.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.4 FIQHack](#FIQHack)
  - [6.5 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Any randomly generated elven broadsword has a base 1⁄20 chance of being made into Orcrist, depending on how many artifacts are generated. Orcrist may be given as a [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") to chaotic, non-[orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") players.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Orcrist is one of two [artifacts](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") in the game that can be [named](/wiki/Name "Name"), which is a property shared with [Sting](/wiki/Sting "Sting"): naming any elven broadsword Orcrist will transform it into the artifact, breaking [illiterate](/wiki/Illiterate "Illiterate") [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct").

## Description

Orcrist grants a +d5 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus and deals [double damage](/wiki/Double_damage "Double damage") against all [orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)") monsters, and like Sting it [warns of orcs](/wiki/Warned_of_monster_type "Warned of monster type") while [wielded](/wiki/Wield "Wield"), glowing blue when any orcs are present on the level.

Also like Sting, Orcrist will not [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast") you unless you are an orc (including via [polyself](/wiki/Polyself "Polyself")), and will not do so otherwise regardless of [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") or [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"). Unlike most artifact weapons, Orcrist does not resist the effects of a cursed [scroll of enchant weapon](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_weapon "Scroll of enchant weapon").

## Strategy

Orcrist is generally not of much use for most roles, unless they lack a solid weapon *and* are able to advance their [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill") in [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword"). Orcs are usually plentiful and also not particularly hard to hit for more combat-proficient roles, even before the +5 to-hit bonus of Orcrist is applied. Those who lack experience dealing with groups of orcs may find it a useful supplement, provided they can find an altar or an elven broadsword to name early enough. A role without a reliable weapon such as a [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") may consider naming Orcrist to get an early medium-damage weapon.

If [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer") has not been generated in a game, [Elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") or [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") can force it as a first gift by naming both Orcrist and Sting before sacrificing: the first sacrifice gift you are given is always co-aligned. Orcish players cannot receive Orcrist this way, meaning that they will instead receive either Stormbringer or [Grimtooth](/wiki/Grimtooth "Grimtooth") for their first gift.

## History

Orcrist first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"), where it was the sole artifact available until the addition of [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"). In Hack 1.0, any weapon could be named Orcrist - this did not transform the weapon, but gave it extra damage against orcs, and could be done with multiple weapons; [Hack 1.0.2](/wiki/Hack_1.0.2 "Hack 1.0.2") restricted the 'creation' of Orcrist this way to [two-handed swords](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword"), though multiple copies were still possible until [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

Orcrist would remain a two-handed sword until [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"), where it was made an [elven broadsword](/wiki/Elven_broadsword "Elven broadsword").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Orcrist](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orcrist "wikipedia:Orcrist")***

In [J.R.R. Tolkien](/wiki/J.R.R._Tolkien "J.R.R. Tolkien")'s *The Hobbit*, Orcrist (known in Sindarin as "Goblin-cleaver") was an elven sword originally forged several millennia ago by high-elven smiths in Gondolin alongside [Glamdring](/wiki/Glamdring "Glamdring"), the sword of King Turgon - like most elven blades, both swords radiated a blue glow whenever orcs were near. Orcrist has a jeweled hilt and high-quality scabbard, with runes on the sword bearing its name - it is described as killing "hundreds of goblins in its time, when the fair Elves of Gondolin hunted them in the hills or did battle before their walls", and was most likely lost during the Fall of Gondolin; it nonetheless became known as the "Biter" among goblins and orcs alike.

Both swords were discovered in a troll-hoard by Thorin's group, with Elrond identifying Orcrist and Thorin promising to honor the sword by killing goblins with it. He would have his chance to do so when he and his company were captured by orcs in the Misty Mountains, who brought them to their kingdom underneath and dragged the group before their ruler, the [Great Goblin](/wiki/Goblin_King "Goblin King"). As he accused Thorin's group of spying, one of their captors held out Orcrist to the Great Goblin, and he and his soldiers were enraged at the sight of the "Biter" that had once felled many of their number. As he then approached Thorin, the great fire that lit the large cavern went out - the Great Goblin was quickly slain by the Glamdring-wielding Gandalf, allowing Bilbo and the dwarves to escape.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") changes Orcrist's alignment from chaotic to lawful, since all elves were changed from chaotic to lawful. Additionally, its to-hit bonus is flat like all [artifact weapons in SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_artifacts "SLASH'EM artifacts"), granting +5 against orcs along with its double damage and a 15% chance of [cancelling](/wiki/Cancel "Cancel") any orc it hits. Orcs as a monster class are more varied and can be much more powerful than in vanilla *NetHack*, making Orcrist slightly more useful for a longer stretch of the game.

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), Orcrist deals an additional +d4 damage to all monsters.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), Orcrist has +1d5 to-hit and double damage against orcs and demons, and warns of them while wielded.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), your god will never give you a nameable artifact such as Orcrist as a sacrifice gift.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) This makes forcing Stormbringer much easier for chaotic characters.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), Orcrist is made of [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") like all other elven weapons, and naming an elven broadsword Orcrist will convert it to copper if it is not already made of that material.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Orcrist is made of [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril"), which deals an additional +1d8 damage to orcish monsters, including orcish players; naming an elven braodsword Orcrist will convert it to mithril if it is not already made of that material. Additionally, Orcrist has a small chance of instantly killing any orc it hits, making it very dangerous if a player orc encounters a hostile monster wielding it.

Orcrist can be combined with Sting at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") to create [Glamdring](/wiki/Glamdring_\(EvilHack\) "Glamdring (EvilHack)"), a mithril elven long sword that shares the orc-warning and orc-slaying abilities of its component artifacts.

## Encyclopedia entry

The Great Goblin gave a truly awful howl of rage when he looked at it, and all his soldiers gnashed their teeth, clashed their shields, and stamped. They knew the sword at once. It had killed hundreds of goblins in its time, when the fair elves of Gondolin hunted them in the hills or did battle before their walls. They had called it Orcrist, Goblin-cleaver, but the goblins called it simply Biter. They hated it and hated worse any one that carried it.

\[ The Hobbit, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]
